"Hey you fucks, don't talk about how a new system could be better, we used to not have it at all"

Good argument OP
Hey you fucks, stop complaining about the free sample sushi being small. People have to pay for it.

oh, btw, the sample sushi is locked inside pretty bento boxes.  You'll get keys to unlock the bento boxes... eventually.

It's taking too long for the free keys to arrive?  That's ok, you can buy keys to enjoy your free sushi.

Free sushi that you can enjoy forever, rather than disappear in five seconds.

Jesus, we get to keep these skins, you know. So what if we have to earn them? Saying that we shouldn't have to earn the things that we generally have to pay for is, well, sounding like some of us feel entitled to it all.

What's next? We can hit gold or plat without needing to play ranked? Do rewards mean nothing nowadays?

So are you saying hextech rewards are earned, or are you saying that they're free?  Those are two opposing viewpoints.

And where did hitting gold and plat come from in this comparison?  You can't buy your way into gold or plat using RP.  You can however buy chests or keys with RP.

Your thoughts are all over the place.  It's like you're just ranting, or arguing just for the sake of arguing.

The first one is Free.

The rest are earned.

*sighs*

Hextech stuff is earned.

It's like answering a quiz question at a booth to get food, rather than a free sushi sample you get with no effort.

There, I think that's a better way to put it. It's a way to get things you would usually pay money for just by playing the game, without necessarily having it handed out either.

I don't think the issue that people have is that they have to earn keys.  The problem is that it's unclear how much work it takes to earn them.  Lets go back to the sushi analogy.

You answer a quiz question at the booth, and get rewarded with a shiny, locked bento box with the promise of some sample sushi inside.  You also get told that you'll get a key to open the bento box over the course of the meal for doing what you were already planning on doing: eating your dinner.

The first key arrives pretty quickly.  You eagerly open it up to find some enticing sushi that you would like to try.  BUT WAIT!  You can't eat that piece of sushi just yet.  You have to open up 3 more bento boxes, and trade in all 4 sushi samples if you want to enjoy one of them.  Or you can choose to open up 2 more bento boxes, and trade in just 3 sushi samples for some other random sushi sample.  Hopefully you don't get one that you're allergic to.

You're pretty good at the whole quiz game, so you start getting bento boxes lined up on your table.  The keys are now coming slowly, but not nearly often enough to keep up with the bento boxes.  You're not nearly as excited about the prospects of the sample sushi, especially now that you've learned that the sample of Banzai Kamikaze Samurai Roll is the most expensive sushi on the menu, so it'll actually take you 8 bento boxes worth of samples to trade in so you can enjoy that Banzai Kamikaze Samurai Roll.

You take a look at the 3 unopened bento boxes on the table that you're still waiting on keys for, and think about the other 3 you'll still need to get and how those will also need keys.  That's when you notice that you can buy bento boxes and keys for a quarter each.

All of a sudden, it doesn't feel so free any more.  It also doesn't feel like you're earning the keys, since they just seem to come out randomly.  Maybe you should just buy some keys and bento boxes.  After all, they're pretty cheap.  In the end, it's like you're buying that Banzai Kamikaze Samurai Roll at a discount.

At least you got a Banzai Kamikaze Samurai Roll.  The guy at the next table got an Asparagus Roll from his bento box.  He said he hates asparagus.  He didn't even bother answering any more quiz questions after that.

So transparency on how it works alongside curbing the whole exponential rate of decrease.

Honestly I don't see why they just don't make it like the FWotD IP bonus, and make a flat cap on what you can earn.

Like, you can earn one key fragment a day (I know that sounds a bit slow) and a chest per week. Put in some pseudo-RNG so you *will* earn a chest at least once every seven days or something. 

Obviously they can't make it too easy (being a business and all), but I guess the problem lies with more how it feels rather than people actually getting the stuff or not. More transparency and "fair" mechanics trumps some  decaying RNG is what I'm hearing.
